full_text:
Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 499-2 Filed 11/23/21 Page 64 of 15963
LBAAMAX3ps Rocchio - Direct
1 Q. At a high level, what are your opinions on which individuals are at higher risk of child sexual abuse based on?
2
3 A. My training and my education, certainly my clinical and forensic experience, as well as my review of the clinical and scientific literature.
4
5 Q. In your education and training, did you learn about the concept of certain groups being at higher risk of childhood sexual abuse?
6
7 A. Yes, because, again, in the phenomenon of child sexual abuse in general, not -- we're looking at vulnerability factors, i.e., who's more at risk. So to the extent that I was learning about ways that you might want to target prevention, for example, where you might want to make those interventions,
8
9 but then also, we know that an individual's prior vulnerabilities interact with their subsequent experiences of victimization and have a profound effect on the outcome, the adverse outcomes of the abuse itself.
10
11 So it was covered in a number of different ways through the course of my education and training.
12
13 Q. In your clinical practice, have you treat and evaluated patients who belong to higher-risk groups?
14
15 A. Yes.
16
17 Q. Can you please explain.
18
19 A. In particular, we know that gender is a higher-risk group, and we know that women and girls are at higher risk for child
20
SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C. (212) 805-0300
DOJ-OGR-00007932

text_blocks.content:
1 Q. At a high level, what are your opinions on which individuals are at higher risk of child sexual abuse based on?
2
3 A. My training and my education, certainly my clinical and forensic experience, as well as my review of the clinical and scientific literature.
4
5 Q. In your education and training, did you learn about the concept of certain groups being at higher risk of childhood sexual abuse?
6
7 A. Yes, because, again, in the phenomenon of child sexual abuse in general, not -- we're looking at vulnerability factors, i.e., who's more at risk. So to the extent that I was learning about ways that you might want to target prevention, for example, where you might want to make those interventions,
8
9 but then also, we know that an individual's prior vulnerabilities interact with their subsequent experiences of victimization and have a profound effect on the outcome, the adverse outcomes of the abuse itself.
10
11 So it was covered in a number of different ways through the course of my education and training.
12
13 Q. In your clinical practice, have you treat and evaluated patients who belong to higher-risk groups?
14
15 A. Yes.
16
17 Q. Can you please explain.
18
19 A. In particular, we know that gender is a higher-risk group, and we know that women and girls are at higher risk for child
